3 STATE OF NEBRASKA DEPARTMENT OF TRADE AND COMMERCE DIVISION OF FIRE PREVENTION Office of State Fire Marshal. lion. Charles W. Bryan, Governor, State of Nebraska. Dear Sir: In compliance with the state law, I respectfully submit to ou the 15th Annual Report of the Division of Fire Pre- vention. The necessity of the work being done by the Fire Pre - vention Department has not as yet been impressed upon the people of our great state. The department seeks and caters to co-operation of the general public in this great life and property saving cause. Many times we are subject to criti - cism for requesting the removal of fire hazards, which, if permitted to remain, would surely lead to the unexpected fire. The service rendered to the public in "Fire Prevention" can well be measured by what has been accomplished in Accident Prevention." To know that in the year 1922 our country's loss of life was about 15,000 and approximately 18,000 painfully burned and injured — many of them being scarred or crippled for life, the major percentage being women and children, to say nothing of the one-half million or more in property destroyed, and Nebraska paying its part in the toll — we must conclude that this is a matter that may not be passed idly by. The only corrective remedy is by the prevention of same. To first accomplish results we must depend upon the co - operation of our citizens in exercising care to prevent fire.

4 It is easy to say that the fire could have been prevented, but it is enough that the country and state have suffered the loss of life and property in the past, of which over eighty per cent was caused by the lack of care, and from this history we may prepare for the future. Very effective and efficient work is being accomplished in this connection by our chambers of commerce, insurance companies, civic leagues and schools, our department co-op - erating as far as possible. We also commend the press for the publicity given to the cause. Too much may not be said in praise of the fire de - partments for the effective and efficient service rendered not only in extinguishing fires but also in the inspection and prevention of fires. Permit me to submit that from 19,157 inspections made during the year, 4,887 disclosed the necessity of a general clean-up of the premises, and 3,837 cases disclosed defective wiring. A thorough investigation has beer, made by an investi - gator in all fires which were presumed to be of "incendiary origin." S. M. Souder, former County Treasurer Lincoln County, North Platte, convicted Dec. 22, 1923, for arson. Sentenced fifteen to twenty years in the state penitentiary . Frank Ambrose, Crete, Saline County, Nebraska. Con - victed of arson Mar. 19, 1923. Sentenced to state peniten - tiary. Appealed to Supreme Court. Frank Crist, Anselmo, Custer County, Nebraska. Pleaded guilty to arson. Sentenced Oct. 19, 1923, to one year in state prison. The department has record of four deaths and eleven in - jured, caused by fire.
